title: Tuesday, 24th November, 2015

11:04 am
PM

But it strikes me as slightly mad

PM

The short strangle involves shorting (selling) both a call option and a put option of the same underlying security. Like a short straddle, the options expire at the same time, but unlike a straddle, the options have different strike prices. The premium can be chosen by the short party, with the hope that this will cover any potential volatility. The short party of the strangle makes a profit if the underlying price stays within the boundaries of the strike price of which they would be exercised, either above or below. Thus, an investor may take a short strangle position if he thinks the underlying security is not at all volatile. This position has limited profit and unlimited risk. A long iron condor is similar, but due to the wings it has limited downside.

But it's largely an exhaustive study of high net worths.

BE

Full of interesting charts that may or may not help your investment thesis.

BE

11:16 am
BE

BE

Have the cheat sheet.

BE

Key themes
- China: Shift from industrialisation to consumption-driven economy evolving quickly. May provide short-term volatility in luxury spending, but supportive longer term.
- IPOs: Data suggest that the IPO market has a high correlation with Chinese luxury spending.
- Travel statistics: Monitoring travel flows (passenger numbers, visas, hotel stats) is increasingly important for outlook; short-term headwinds, long term attractive.
- Pricing: Price harmonisation being ‘the new norm’. Gradual changes marginneutral, but sudden catch-up shifts dilutive.
- Rent: Improved rental negotiation coming through in Asia, mainly for larger-scale participants.
- Consensus: Forecasts too high for FY16, weaker organic growth expected.
- Valuation: Risk of de-rating despite strong balance sheets.

11:17 am
BE

Key stock calls
- Kering – Gucci product gaining traction, shops refitted, younger customer attracted. Risks include lack of product availability, investment and alienating core customer. Puma sale optionality, but not expected in the near term.
- LVMH – Defensive and diversified, strength in wider brand portfolio, increased shareholders returns possible. Risks include LV brand space review in Asia, further destocking in China Cognac.
- Swatch – Downgrade to Neutral, high correlation with Swiss watch data, implied -2% cc in 2H and margins down greater than 200bp. Ongoing risks to consensus expectations, although valuation and asset support supportive.
- Burberry – Downgrade to Neutral. Finely balanced investment case, strong seasonal product line-up, but ambitious rebound in LFL expected, indicating downside risk to consensus expectations. Japan gaining traction, strong balance sheet and digital positioning the positives.
- Adidas – Retain Neutral. Short-term concerns on valuation, however structural growth trend in sporting goods and product/brand momentum makes segment attractive on a relative basis.
- Tods/Hugo Boss downgraded to Reduce. Headwinds for FY16 earnings. Expect price harmonisation in Asia for Hugo Boss and also wholesale headwinds in the US, while Tod’s group has mixed performance and LFL under pressure.
- Prada – Retain Reduce rating. Brand momentum remains weak into 3Q trading. Some progress in rent renegotiation, but we believe the group remains overcosted and under-invested (eg, online).

BE

Global views
- US team: Given the strength of the USD, our US analysts prefer stocks with limited international exposure and tourist-related sales (SIG, ULTA, EXPR and AEO) and companies with credible long-term growth plans (NKE, TIF, COH).
- HK/Chinese team: Chinese tourist diversion away from HK and China is a structural challenge (Reduce ratings on Chow Tai Fook, Luk Fook and SaSa).
- Japan: City-centre department stores in Japan will benefit from Chinese tourist flows (Marui Group, Seven & I holdings, Sundrug, Nitori Holding, Start Today, and United Arrows).
- South Korea: Travel retail, luxury hotels and beauty-related consumer goods companies benefit from a Chinese client base (Hotel Shilla, Hanssem, Amorepacific, LG H&H, and Medy-Tox).

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 146.80, down 16.2 (-9.94%), High: 165.40, Low: 144.60, Volume: 545.71k

11:23 am
BE

PM

hmm, fair point

BE

Let me cut to some Cazenove to show where figures are going.

11:23 am
BE

AO’s H116 sales growth was strong and in line with our expectations, with
UK AO website sales up 24% in H116 and over 30% in Q216. AO has chosen
to invest heavily in advertising & marketing (A&M) in the UK (+55% to
£12.2m) and Germany (£3m) in the period. Along with some inefficiency as a
result of the uneven volume growth in H116 (slower than expected in Q116,
rapid in Q216), this has contributed to a group EBITDA loss of £-4.5m (H115
£7.3m EBITDA profit). We do not expect a further step-up in UK A&M
spend in H216, and expect negligible further volume-related inefficiency.
Nonetheless, the H116 loss, and an assumed step-up in A&M spend in
Germany in H216, lead us to reduce our FY16 group EBITDA forecast from a
profit of £5.6m to a loss of -£3.6m. We expect the shares to open lower this
morning given this downgrade, although we believe that many will welcome
the decision to increase A&M investment to drive sales growth.

BE

 UK adjusted EBITDA profit was £5.1m (H115 £7.3m). The fall in profit
was due to two main factors. First, investment in A&M increased from
£7.9m to £12.2m (from 3.6% to 4.9% as a percentage of sales). This was
driven by TV advertising to increase brand awareness, and AO is very
pleased with the results. Second, AO experienced some inefficiencies due to
lower than expected volume in Q116 (with consequently lower than
expected operational leverage), and then due to the adjustment required to
meet the much higher volume growth in Q216 (with extra staffing being the
most obvious challenge. We reduce our FY16 UK EBITDA forecast to
£17m (previously £19m), broadly in line the guidance that AO is “on track
with our plans for the year as a whole” (with company-compiled consensus
being for UK EBITDA of c.£16m).

BE

 Europe adjusted EBITDA loss was -£9.6m (H115 nil). We increase our
Europe FY16 EBITDA loss forecast to -£20.5m (previously -£14.5m) due to
earlier than expected heavy investment in A&M and also higher “Other
admin costs”. This is in line with the guidance that “at least” the same level
of net P&L investment will be made in H216 as in H116 in Germany.

11:23 am
BE

 AO has announced that its next market will be the Netherlands. It
expects to enter this market in Spring 2016.

BE

That Netherlands launch is quite useful in terms of press coverage. It means this morning's headlines are all "AO going to Holland" rather than "AO cuts guidance again"

PM

Caz are the house, yes?

11:25 am
BE

I'd imagine so, but haven't checked.

PM

Yes, they are for sure

PM

Led the float

11:25 am
BE

Numis also on the ticket, IIRC.

BE

Still buyers. Andrew Wade's the analyst.

BE

While AO's H1 UK EBITDA was impacted by inefficiencies and marketing
investment, the strong top-line acceleration since, a normalised cost profile and a
good start to H2 should see FY consensus unchanged. While we increase our FY
German EBITDA loss, we see clear progress being made and are encouraged by
the Netherlands launch in Spring 2016. We remain positive.
● Strong UK acceleration driven by marketing investment: H1 UK adj. EBITDA of
£5.1m (PY £7.3m) reflected a 140bp YOY reduction in EBITDA margin to 2.0% and
was impacted by the combination of a significant marketing investment (+130bp/£4.3m
YOY), as trailed at Q2, and variable cost inefficiencies caused by the volatile trading
pattern (last mile, warehousing, call centre). While H1 profitability was below par, we
believe the marketing investment is the correct strategic approach – brand awareness
has increased ‘significantly’ and AO.com UK growth accelerated to c.+32% in Q2 –
and the inefficiencies should fall away as growth resumes a more steady path. As a
result, with H2 having started ‘well’, and a more normal cost profile likely, we leave our
FY16 UK EBITDA forecast unchanged at c.£16m.
● Other factors worth noting: 1) UK gross margin increased by 40bp despite last
mile inefficiencies, mix pressure from AV, and a c.7% ASP reduction (in-category mix
and competition), the benefit of investment in UK category teams. 2) 3rd Party Retail
(3PR) and 3rd Party Logistics (3PL) revenues declined by 23% and 19% respectively,
reflecting shrinking sales from competitor websites and the logistics contract loss last
year. 3) NPS scores remain exceptionally high and repeat purchase metrics have
continued to improve. 4) Progress in the AV and SDA categories has been ‘pleasing’.
● Progress in Germany, Netherlands next: German revenue grew solidly, reaching
€21.7m (NSe €25.5m) and with a September exit rate of €5.1m (NSe €5.7m). The
progress made has given management confidence to invest ‘heavily’ in marketing and
it now expects to maintain a similar level of investment in H2 (H1 EBITDA loss £9.6m).
Reflecting this, along with slower product margin gains, we increase our FY16 forecast
EBITDA loss from £18m to £21m. Nevertheless, clear progress is being made, with
range improving, exceptional customer feedback, a new DC to open in 2016, and
protection plans now launched. Encouraged by this, AO has today announced that it will
expand into its next territory, the Netherlands, in Spring 2016; there will be some small
early set-up costs but this operation will largely leverage the German infrastructure.

11:26 am
BE

And Jefferies. Also buyers, not shop.

BE

In conclusion. This set of results will have an impact on short term profitability; however, that doesn't take away from our positive thesis around AO. It is a revenue growth story fueled by investment in brand and foreign expansion. As we have said before, AO is probably not the stock to deliver EBITDA margin accretion on a three-year view. It is a bit disappointing that the company hasn't provided the tangible guide that we had hoped for, given the timing of the announcement with the year end in March. We still believe that the eCommerce world lacks visibility and potentially the lumpy nature of the MDA category makes AO even less transparent. Nevertheless, it is currently trading on 0.8x CY16 EV/Sales, peers on 1.4x - a discount we don't think is warranted.

BE

Even Shore's a buyer.

11:27 am
BE

Short-term multiples remain astronomical, with a current EV/EBITDA for the full year of c134 times, falling to 65 times in FY2017.Our recommendation remains unchanged and we retain a BUY stance, however we believe that the potentially challenging third quarter (against an erratic retail environment thus far in October and November) combined with a headline operating loss for the first half (albeit anticipated) will see bears take an active position on the stock and the share price may possibly suffer in the near-term. We have adopted a longer term view, underpinned by the belief that the business will deliver on its strategy and will become sufficiently profitable with scale.

BE

Overwhelming sellside support. Fair enough. Take your pick, I guess.

Today is our annual charity day.
All our trading commissions will be donated to War Child, an amazing charity that do incredible things for children in conflict zones (so, quite topical!). Without education these children are vulnerable to joining the perpetrators of these atrocities, who give them purpose. If we allow this we may one day risk our own children to terrorist attacks like those seen in Paris. So, as parents, we plead for your help in supporting them today. To learn more about our involvement, or to donate please click on this link:

https://www.warchild.org.uk/aviate-2015
There are a lot of good ideas today some of which are even actionable.....(rare for me I know!). Stock names include: Serco, Compass, Swedish Match, Ubisoft, Anheuser-Busch, Intertek, Pearson, Sage, Altice, Whitbread, UCB, Grifols, Roche, Thales, Safran, Rolls Royce, Allianz, Kuka, Swatch, Accor, VOW, Peugeot, GlaxoSmithKline.

PM

undefined
11:32 am
BE

I ought to note, very much in passing, that Berenberg's not too keen on Pearson either this morning.

BE

Dividend unsustainable: While we understand management’s
commitment to the dividend, and the fact that Pearson’s disposal
programme means it can “afford” to pay, we think the company needs to
rebase the pay-out. Sooner or later this has to happen, we think. We expect
a new chairman to make that decision in early 2016, when the outlook for
the year becomes clearer

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 794.50, down 22 (-2.69%), High: 810.00, Low: 787.50, Volume: 1.02m

BE

PM

Anyway, they can still sack us. Best move on

BE

(@Roddy: oi.)

BE

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 91.83, up 1.41 (+1.56%), High: 93.40, Low: 90.18, Volume: 22.68m
BE

11:36 am
PM

PM

BE

Anyway, today's sector review comes from Merrill

11:36 am
BE

Which downgrades Anto

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 480.50, down 15.7 (-3.16%), High: 495.90, Low: 478.90, Volume: 1.41m
BE

Only other change is on Anglo's dividend, which still hasn't been cut.

11:38 am
BE

Don't understand why. Surely management has an obligation to tell investors they won't be getting the previously guided yield as soon as they themselves know?

PM

Well you'd think so

BE

Perhaps there's a reason they're delaying. I don't know what that reason is.

11:38 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 439.55, down 1.6 (-0.36%), High: 458.70, Low: 437.50, Volume: 3.21m
PM

you could argue that if they don't know it's being cut they are perhaps not fit and proper...

BE

Well, indeed.

11:39 am
BE

Let me get the top line here. It's the usual: lots of forecast cuts and not a lot of colour.

BE

Key
views / changes today: Copper see $4000 by Q4 2016. iron ore, $45/t in 2015, 2016 (no
change). LT iron ore -12% to $55/t (2016$). Coals downgraded near and longer term.
2016E thermal coal -10% to US$47/t. LT downgraded 15% to US$50/t (2016$). We
assume the seaborne market shrinks. 2016E coking coal -17% to US$75/t. LT coking
coal -12% to US$95/t (2016$).

BE

We remain cautious as China slows & miners deal with the impact of flattening cost
curves on balance sheet & dividends

11:40 am
BE

Iron ore and coal. Downgraded. Copper: Previous bounce in 2017 now delayed, cuts
(e.g. 400kt from GLEN) indicates market bottoming. Aluminium: China’s improved
competitiveness & low capital intensity an overhang. Nickel, Zinc: Supply story fine,
demand, particularly in China not. Diamonds: Destocking near term

BE

China, as ever is key at 50% of demand for most commodities. Property is a key source
of end-demand. While some are discussing “Green Shoots” of recovery for housing, we
think that the wider picture remains mixed. Per capita consumption of many materials at
“saturation” & funding for infrastructure and property is challenging. We also see
bifurcation in the property market with Tier 1 and Tier 2 city prices rising but some Tier
2 and many Tier 3 and 4 cities struggling with excess inventory. We note recent efforts
by China to support stock market & stimulate growth which have had mixed effects.
China’s steel industry does seem to be hitting a critical point, with increased closures
which will put steel-making raw material pricing under pressure near term.

BE

And on stock calls ...............

11:40 am
BE

BHP Billiton (Neutral): With some 25-30% of revenues from Petroleum, we see BHP as
a more defensive exposure to the sector and as such “less bad” than peers which may
be overexposed to iron ore. We think that recent comments by the Chairman suggest
that the company will contemplate a dividend cut and we have cut our assumed dividend
to US$0.62 (about 4.4% yield). We think that the recent Samarco tragedy in Brazil could
bring forward debate around an “appropriate” dividend payment based on the ongoing,
sustainable profit potential of the business. We believe that the company’s spin-off of
South32 should focus the business and create value for shareholders. Shares trade on
0.7x our DCF derived NPV, the lower end of the company’s historical trading range.

BE

Think Neil Collins did the argument over the weekend that BHP should cut its divi, even though it doesn't have any immediate pressure to.

BE

Same was true of BP post Macondo, which became a saga that created a lot of extra unnecessary pressure for Mr Hayward.

11:42 am
BE

Anyway, back to Merrill.

BE

Rio Tinto (Underperform): Rio Tinto is geared first and foremost to iron ore (around
50% of revenues, about 75% of EBITDA in 2014). While shares look “cheap” on DCF
and FCF looks reasonable vs. peers until iron ore finds a bottom we think that shares are
a classic “value trap” i.e. cheap plus a falling commodity price. We do acknowledge
management’s success at cutting costs and driving capital efficiency. In other products,
copper volumes have continued to disappoint with government relations at Oyu Tolgoi
in Mongolia having stalled at an impasse for a while (but now moving ahead it appears).
Aluminium had improved markedly over the last few years but we have now seen the
collapse in premiums in the US and Europe as warehouse queues shorten & exports of
Chinese semis ramp. China’s historic “high cost” position in aluminium looks to be in
question as coal prices fall and grid charges are lowered. To us, the threat of Chinese
exports caps upside potential in aluminium.

BE

Glencore (Neutral): Glencore’s key commodity exposures are copper & thermal coal. We
are cautious on copper near term, seeing downside to US$4513/t in 2016 despite a
generally positive “street view” on copper in the medium term. For thermal coal, where
Glencore is one of the largest global suppliers (about 10% of the seaborne market), the
outlook is very poor, in our view. China has changed its policy on imports and we think
this could be very negative for seaborne coal demand. GLEN’s credit was recently
moved to negative outlook by S&P. While we think that a 1 notch downgrade would
have little impact on the business near term, we do think that the capital structure looks
a little stretched for where we are in the commodity cycle ($50 bn is a lot of debt). That
said, GLEN has just announced a $10 bn debt reduction plan including a $2.5 bn equity
raise, (more) capex cuts, asset sales & reduction in working capital. We upgraded to
Neutral on the announced equity raise. Glencore’s commodity marketing (trading)
business is a point of differentiation vs. peers theoretically providing diversification and
releasing capital in commodity downcycles. Though, we note that trading earnings
disappointed vs. street expectations in H1 2015 results.

11:42 am
BE

Anglo American (Underperform): Top down, we like Anglo’s exposure to late
development commodities, like diamonds and platinum. Unfortunately, Anglo is just
commissioning its Minas Rio iron ore mega-project in Brazil, “doubling down” on iron
ore at possibly the worst moment in the cycle. Anglo has a geared balance sheet & will
be cash flow negative after dividends for the next few years. While the company has
ample liquidity, we don’t think the equity market will reward this approach. The
company has completed some asset sales including its stake in the Tarmac Lafarge JV
(about US$1.8 bn) and Anglo Norte US$300 mn in proceeds. We think that a sale of
identified non-core assets could also help allay market concerns on Anglo’s balance
sheet. We note that S&P has recently placed Anglo on negative credit watch.

BE

And finally ..............

BE

Antofagasta (downgrade to UNDERPERFORM):
While we like Antofagasta’s unlevered balance sheet and believe that a dividend policy
based on a payout ratio is (more) appropriate (than many peer policies, we can’t get
away from our cautious house view on the copper price.
Our metals analyst, Michael Widmer, models copper touching $4000 in Q4 2016. We
don’t think shares will outperform the market or peers with a key commodity under
pressure.
Anto has also struggled lately to deliver operationally with the Centinela assets in
particular not yet delivering stable operation. The acquisition of the Zaldivar mine,
earlier this year, took place at a premium to NPV (in our view) in a falling market for the
commodity.
Looking to 2016, the ramp-up of the group’s new Antucoya mine brings some
production growth but also risks on volumes. During periods of high dividend payouts
and operational excellence, Anto shares traded on a premium Of late, with dividends
under pressure from lower metal prices & operational excellence not a given, we see
potential for a further derating of shares.
Our PO is set at 0.8x our NPV, a discount to Anto’s historic premium rating but inline
with most of our large cap miner price objectives.

FY2016 interims in line: PBT +14% to £213.6m (PHe £203.1m). Revenues +12%
(+10% organic at constant fx) to £2,349.2m. EBITA +6% (+8% organic at constant
fx) to £253.0m as the operating margin decreased by 0.6% to 10.8%. EPS +11% to
34.5p (tax rate 17% vs. 18%, no. of shares +4%) and DPS +10% to 6.05p. Marine
& Technology (33% of FY15 group profits) profits +11% to £86.4m (margin 0.1% to
10.8%) driven by strong performance by the naval business, including growth in
warship refit programmes and QEC carrier procurement activity. There were also
increased activity levels in the Australian Naval Ship Management JV and new
Dockyard Management contract in New Zealand. Defence& Security (25%) profits
+4% to £60.6m (margin +0.9% to 15.0%), on revenues down 3% (as previously
flagged) due to the completion of the Regional Prime contracts in 2H FY15 and
the planned phasing of airtanker deliveries. The integration of DSG (acquired
1April) has started well. Revenue is expected to improve in 2H, benefiting from the
anticipated ward of the UK MFTS fixed wing programme in 3Q. Support Services
(19%) profits +16% to £47.4m (margin down 0.8% to 7.3%) on revenues +30%
largely driven by the Magnox contract. International (22%) profits down 4% to
£61.6m (margin down 0.9% to 14.9%). At constant fx South African revenues
declined by 5% with the progress in the power business being outweighed by the
impact from the weakness in commodity prices on the equipment business. Mission
Critical Services revenues +4% at constant fx with a 9% decline in the oil & gas
business due to renewed oil piece weakness, offset by growth of 10% in the
Emergency Services business. For the full year management now expect growth at
constant fx of 0% compared to between 0% and 5% previously. The group order
book is £20bn (May 2015 £20bn) and provides 92% revenue visibility for FY16
and % for FY17. During the period year Babcock achieved a win rate of c40% on
new contracts and over 90% on rebids. The pipeline is £10.5bn (May 2015
£10.5bn).

Consensus FY16E EPS estimates are likely to remain unchanged. In their outlook comments management stress that “we continue to make good progress and our full year results will be in line with our expectations”. The order book provides visibility over 92% of anticipated FY16E turnover and Babcock believe the UK Government’s strategic defence review yesterday “supports our view regarding future outsourcing opportunities”.

Reiterate Buy rating. We think the group’s 12.2x CY16E PE multiple sits at an undeserved discount to Capita (16.3x), G4S (13.1x), and Serco (41x) and towards the bottom of the 9-19x through the cycle historical range. Excluding the additional cash pension contribution, the FY17E FCF yield is 6%.

PM

Usual themes, but will share in any case

PM

US/Canada luxury marketing feedback: still an unloved sector

We met

30 investors in the US and Canada last week and found that sentiment in luxury stocks remains unsurprisingly bearish given deteriorating trends in Asia/Americas in 3Q and mounting concerns over a potential slowdown in Chinese tourist activity in Europe. Investors see these headwinds putting further downward pressure on consensus forecasts as we enter the critical festive season. Investors continue to question the structural long-term growth potential of leading brands in Greater China, especially for watches and for the sector mega-brands, which should see some rationalisation of their net selling space in Greater China next year, in our view.

The main positives for the sector remain: (a) favourable FX environment (given prospects of rising US interest rates, potential further QE in Europe and potential further rate cuts by the SNB) and (b) lower short-term expectations (e.g. we forecast zero organic growth for Richemont & Swatch Group in the next six months) after several dreadful industry data points (e.g. Swiss watch exports down 12% in October). Last, most investors see Sporting Goods as a relative bright spot in our coverage as we go into 2016.

11:57 am
PM

But we noticed rising / selective investor interest in a few names for 2016

At this time of the year, it is not surprising to see investors looking at some laggards YTD as potential stock ideas for 2016. Two names stood out in terms of investor interest in our trip: Richemont (best jewellery play in our view and relatively resilient margin profile in a low growth environment; greater interest coming from long-term investors) and Kering (more constructive sentiment on Gucci turnaround and focus on valuation ex-Puma, greater interest from hedge funds). We also feel that Moncler remains a 'consensual long' in our coverage among US investors.

Conversely, investor interest was relatively low on LVMH (maybe due to material outperformance and relative re-rating YTD), Hermes (which also outperformed YTD), Salvatore Ferragamo, Tod's Group and Prada Group (owing to their poor SSSG momentum). Positive sentiment among long-term investors on Richemont contrasts with overwhelmingly bearish sentiment on Swatch Group, which remains the sector's top contrarian call. We saw a marked deterioration in sentiment on Burberry Group (historically a well-owned stock by US investors) compared to our last US trip six months ago.
